questions.text: A chronic alcohol user who has been regularly consuming 6 pegs of alcohol daily for the past 15 years now experiences marked intoxication after consuming just 1 peg. Which of the following best describes his altered physiological response?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Long-term alcohol use can cause reverse tolerance, where the brain becomes more sensitive to alcohol, and even small amounts produce stronger effects like sedation and intoxication.

  • When higher doses of a substance are required to achieve the same effect, it's known as tolerance, while reverse tolerance is the phenomenon in which lower doses of the same drug or substance produce a more pronounced effect.
  • Reverse tolerance is caused by the supersensitivity of receptors and can result from organ damage.
  • Examples for drugs of abuse showing reverse tolerance: Cocaine, Alcohol, Amphetamine, MDMA (Ecstasy).

Explanation of other options:

Dependence (Option A): Dependence refers to the repeated use of a drug or chemical substance, cessation of which can result in withdrawal symptoms.

Drugs showing both psychological and physical dependence: Heroin, Morphine, Cannabis

Drugs with psychological dependence only: LSD, MDMA (Ecstasy), Cocaine

Tolerance (Option B): Phenomenon in which repeated administration of a drug results in decreased effect or when larger doses of the same drug are required to produce the same effect experienced with the initial dose. Most drugs of abuse develop tolerance: Eg, opioids, Cannabis, Amphetamine, LSD, and Nicotine.

Abuse (Option D): Abuse refers to the use of any drug or substance in a manner that deviates from approved social or medical patterns, resulting in negative consequences.

questions.text: After the complete management of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which of the following conditions can remain despite the treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Wernicke's encephalopathy is completely reversible with treatment; however, residual symptoms such as ataxia and horizontal nystagmus may persist.

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy, also called as alcoholic encephalopathy, is an alcohol-induced persistent amnestic disorder.
  • Resulting from thiamine deficiency, it is most commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, sometimes in malnutrition.
  • Classic triad in the sequence of symptom appearance:
    • Global Confusion
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia results in horizontal nystagmus due to 6th nerve palsy > 3rd nerve palsy.
  • Ophthalmoplegia is the earliest symptom to recover.
  • Treatment of Wernicke's encephalopathy involves high doses of parenteral thiamine.

Key Takeaways:

Classic Triad of Wernicke's Encephalopathy: (In sequence of symptom appearance)

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Ataxia

questions.text: A high-profile person wishes to cease alcohol consumption. However, he doesn't want to take disulfiram as he has to attend high-profile meetings with his clients and also assert the need to consume alcohol sometimes in professional settings. What should be prescribed next?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In this scenario, as the person doesn't want to use disulfiram due to the need for occasional alcohol consumption in professional settings, Acamprosate, an anti-craving medication, can be an effective alternative.
  • Anticraving medications help reduce the desire to drink and decrease the risk of relapse.
  • Anticraving agents:
    • Naltrexone
    • Acamprosate
    • Topiramate
    • Gabapentin
    • Ondensatron
    • Fluoxetine and Baclofen

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is brought to the emergency department 3 days after his last drink. He is agitated, diaphoretic, and confused, with visual hallucinations and coarse tremors. His blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, and his heart rate is 112 beats per minute. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The above presentation is classic for delirium tremens, a medical emergency which occurs 48-72 hours post-cessation.

Delirium tremens is used to describe severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome, characterised by:

  • Delirium (mental confusion, agitation and altered level of consciousness)
  • Hallucinations (Visual and tactile)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity(tremor, sweating and tachycardia)

Delirium Tremens is effectively treated with intravenous Lorazepam and thiamine.

Explanation of other options:

Injection Thiamine (Option A): Thiamine administration alone does not control alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Rather large doses of parenteral thiamine help with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy and prevent progression into Korsakoff's syndrome.

Olanzapine (Option B) and Haloperidol with Thiamine (Option D): Olanzapine and haloperidol are both antipsychotic medications. Antipsychotic medications are known to reduce the seizure threshold in patients. Hence avoided in withdrawal where seizure risk is already high.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic presents 48 hours after abrupt alcohol cessation. Laboratory results reveal normal liver and renal function. Which drug is most appropriate for alcohol detoxification in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Benzodiazepines are used to control the symptoms associated with alcohol withdrawal.
  • Long-acting benzodiazepines like chlordiazepoxide and diazepam are generally preferred in patients with normal LFT because they produce active metabolites, resulting in prolonged action and have self-tapering effects.

Explanation for other options:

Lorazepam (Option A): Short-acting benzodiazepines (Lorazepam, Oxazepam) have a shorter half-life and bypass hepatic metabolism, thus making them safer in patients with liver dysfunction.

Haloperidol (Option C): Haloperidol is a potent antipsychotic drug. Since antipsychotic medications lower the seizure threshold, they are avoided.

Alprazolam (Option D): Alprazolam is not recommended for treating alcohol withdrawal syndrome (AWS) due to its high abuse potential and no proven benefit.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is most commonly associated with performance enhancement, particularly in contexts requiring increased alertness, focus, or physical endurance?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • As a general class, amphetamines are referred to as:
    • Analeptics (CNS stimulants)
    • Sympathomimetics (adrenergic agonists)
    • Stimulants and psychostimulants (dopamine/norepinephrine enhancers).
  • These are used to enhance performance and to induce a euphoric feeling.

Explanation for other options:

Benzodiazepines (Option A): Benzodiazepines are CNS depressants that potentiate GABA receptor activity, inducing sedation, anxiolysis, muscle relaxation, and anticonvulsant effects.

Alcohol (Option B): Alcohol produces dose-dependent CNS depression.

Cannabis (Option C): Produces mixed effects of relaxation and mild euphoria similar to alcohol.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use is brought to the emergency department with complaints of frequent yawning, rhinorrhea, lacrimation, diarrhoea and muscle aches. On examination, he is sweating, has piloerection, and dilated pupils. He reports that he has not used the drug for the past 24 hours. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Above-described symptoms are classic Opioid Withdrawal.

Commonly abused Opioids include Heroin, Morphine, Codeine, and Methadone.

Heroin (street names "smack" and "brown sugar") is the most abused opioid and has the highest addiction.

Withdrawal symptoms of opioids: Usually appear 6-8 hours after the last dose, peak during 2-3rd day and subside during 7-10th.

  • Flu-like syndrome with symptoms like rhinorrhea, Lacrimation, sweating, diarrhoea
  • Yawning and piloerection (goose flesh or cold turkey).
  • Pupillary dilation (mydriasis)
  • Muscle cramps and generalised body aches
  • Insomnia, anxiety, HTN, tachycardia
  • Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia

Treatment:

Detoxification:

  • The detoxification phase usually lasts for 2-3 weeks. Methadone (a full Opioid agonist) and buprenorphine (a Partial Opioid agonist) are drugs usually used.
  • For the next 4-5 days, the Accelerated Detoxification starts with Naltrexone (Opioid antagonist), followed by clonidine (to manage withdrawal symptoms).

Maintenance treatment:

The phase of craving control and relapse prevention prevents relapse and is done by 2 methods.

  • Opioid substitution therapy: Short-acting opioids like heroin are substituted by long-acting methadone and buprenorphine.
  • Opioid antagonist treatment: Naltrexone, the longest-acting (72 hours) opioid antagonist, is used. They act by blocking opioid agonist effects, particularly euphoria, discouraging persons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour and, thus, deconditioning this behaviour.

Non-pharmacological approaches: CBT, family therapy

Explanation of other options:

Ganja (Option B), Cannabis (Option C): Cannabis preparations are obtained from the plant Cannabis sativa and are available in various strengths as hemp, chasra, bhang, ganja, dagga.

In daily cannabis users, cessation of use can result in withdrawal symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks. Withdrawal symptoms include: insomnia, irritability, anxiety, low mood, restlessness, tremors, vivid dreaming, decreased appetite, weight loss, and headache.

Alcohol (Option D): Alcohol withdrawal presents with tremors, hallucinations, seizures, and delirium tremens, marked by visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, and delirium.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with chronic alcohol use is hospitalised for pneumonia. Two days after admission, he develops anxiety, tremors, sweating, and flushing. On evaluation, he is febrile, hypertensive and tachycardic. Physical exam reveals diaphoresis and a coarse bilateral hand tremor. Lab tests show mildly elevated AST, ALT, and GGT. His last drink was the day before admission. Which medication is most appropriate for managing his current condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The patient's history, clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with a history of regular, heavy alcohol use and are most likely experiencing acute alcohol withdrawal.

  • Lorazepam and oxazepam are both well-supported options for benzodiazepine withdrawal, especially in patients with liver compromise.
  • Acute alcohol withdrawal is characterised by signs of sympathetic nervous system stimulation such as:
    • Elevated vital signs
    • Diaphoresis
    • Flushing
    • Tremor
    • Insomnia and anxiety
  • It can occur anywhere between 1 and 4 days after cessation or a significant reduction in alcohol intake.
  • Other complications of alcohol withdrawal include:
    • Withdrawal seizures (12-48 hours after the last drink)
    • Delirium tremens (24-96 hours after the last drink)

Treatment for Acute alcohol withdrawal:

  • Benzodiazepines are the first-line agents for alcohol withdrawal using a CIWA-triggered approach, which leads to reduced duration and lower doses compared to fixed regimens
    • If LFT normal: Chlordiazepoxide, diazepam
    • If LFT abnormal: Lorazepam, Oxazepam
  • Thiamine in large doses is given to prevent progression to Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Explanation of other options:

Acamprosate (Option A): Acamprosate is not appropriate for treating alcohol withdrawal; rather, they are used in managing alcohol dependence as it reduces craving and promotes abstinence.

Disulfiram (Option B): The primary indication for disulfiram use is as an aversive conditioning treatment for alcohol dependence and is not used to manage alcohol withdrawal.

Diazepam (Option D): Benzodiazepines like diazepam and chlordiazepoxide are used for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms in individuals with deranged LFT.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by family members. She is disoriented, agitated, and unable to answer questions. She stumbles while walking and appears unsteady on her feet. On examination, she has horizontal nystagmus, poor coordination, and a strong odour of alcohol on her breath. She resists further examination and becomes combative. Family members give a history of chronic alcohol use. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • This patient presents with Wernicke encephalopathy, the most appropriate treatment for which is immediate administration of thiamine.

Wernicke's encephalopathy:

  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is characterised by the triad of global confusion, ataxia and ophthalmoplegia.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy, also called as alcoholic encephalopathy, is an alcohol-induced persistent amnestic disorder.
  • Resulting from thiamine deficiency, it is most commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, sometimes in malnutrition.
  • Ophthalmoplegia results in horizontal nystagmus due to 6th nerve palsy > 3rd nerve palsy.
  • Ophthalmoplegia is the earliest symptom to recover.
  • Treatment of Wernicke's encephalopathy involves high doses of parenteral thiamine.
  • Thiamine must be given before glucose in patients suspected of having this disorder.

Explanation of other options:

Antipsychotic (Option A): Antipsychotics are used in agitated patients during the treatment of alcohol withdrawal. However, they are generally not advised as they lower the seizure threshold.

Benzodiazepines (Option B): Benzodiazepines are first-line agents for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal symptoms. In this case, the patient has Wernicke's encephalopathy and not just alcohol withdrawal.

Disulfiram (Option C): The primary indication for disulfiram use is as an aversive conditioning treatment for alcohol dependence and is not used to manage Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Treatment of Wernicke's encephalopathy: Parenteral Thiamine.
  • The earliest symptom to resolve following Thiamine administration in Wernicke's encephalopathy is ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a 30-year history of heavy alcohol use is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to increasing confusion. She reports that over the past year, he has consumed less food, preferring alcohol to large meals, and has experienced significant weight loss. His last drink was earlier today. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on his mental status examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

This patient has a long history of heavy, regular alcohol use and likely malnutrition. A common sequel of this is chronic thiamine deficiency, resulting in Korsakoff syndrome.

Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome:

  • The classic names for alcohol-induced persisting amnestic disorder are Wernicke's encephalopathy (a set of acute symptoms) and Korsakoff's syndrome (a chronic neurological condition).
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is completely reversible with treatment, but only about 20 per cent of patients with Korsakoff's syndrome recover.
  • The pathophysiological connection between the two syndromes is thiamine deficiency.
  • Korsakoff syndrome is characterised by :
    • Impaired recent memory
    • Anterograde amnesia > retrograde amnesia
  • This memory impairment is often poorly compensated for by the patient's confabulation (filling in the missing memories with false information).
  • The treatment of Korsakoff syndrome focuses on Thiamine replacement - oral Thiamine supplementation for 3-12 months.

Symptoms of alcohol withdrawal include tremor, agitation, tachycardia, and hypertension. Tremor is the most characteristic sign of alcohol withdrawal.

Explanation of other options:

Delusions (Option A): Delusions are more typical of alcohol hallucinosis or schizophrenia. Korsakoff's patients lack psychotic features-they are disoriented but not paranoid.

Elevated Affect (Option B): Seen in mania or stimulant intoxication, not Korsakoff's.

Fluctuating Consciousness (Option D): Suggests delirium tremens, not chronic Korsakoff's. DTs occur in acute withdrawal with symptoms like tachycardia, tremors, hallucinations, and there is no gradual memory loss.

Key takeaway:

Korsakoff syndrome:

  • Chronic neurological complications
  • Seen in chronic alcoholism
  • Characterised by impaired recent memory and anterograde amnesia.
  • Treatment: Oral Thiamine for 3-12 months.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of alcohol and cocaine dependence is admitted to psychiatry for depression, suicidal ideation, and detoxification. Which of the following is the most characteristic early sign of alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Tremor is the most characteristic sign of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Hypertension and tachycardia occur in alcohol withdrawal because of autonomic hyperactivity and not hypotension. (Option A)
  • Insomnia (not hypersomnia) is typical in alcohol withdrawal; hypersomnia is seen in cocaine withdrawal. (Option B).
  • Hallucinations associated with alcohol withdrawal usually resolve within a week, while those occurring in delirium tremens typically resolve with the delirium (Option C).

Key Takeaways:

  • Alcohol withdrawal: Tremors, agitation, tachycardia, hypertension.
  • Cocaine withdrawal: Fatigue, hypersomnia, increased appetite.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with a history of heavy alcohol use is admitted for elective surgery. He reports drinking consistently up until admission, but is now unable to drink during his hospital stay. Given his recent alcohol cessation, when is he at highest risk for developing severe alcohol withdrawal complications, including life-threatening symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The symptoms experienced by the patient are suggestive of Delirium tremens, which develops within the first 72 hours up to 1 week following the last drink.

Delirium tremens:

  • It's the most severe form of the withdrawal symptom and is considered a medical emergency.
  • DTs can occur anytime within the first 72 hours up to 1 week.

Symptoms of Alcohol Withdrawal:

Tremors are the 1st and the most common symptom in alcohol withdrawal. Tremors in alcohol withdrawal are coarse tremors.

  • The classic sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness, and tremors are the 1st and the most common symptom in alcohol withdrawal.
  • Tremors in alcohol withdrawal are coarse tremors.

Key Takeaways:

Withdrawal symptoms usually, but not always, occur in stages:

  • Tremulousness or jitteriness: 6-8 hours
  • Psychosis and perceptual symptoms: 8-12 hours
  • Seizures: 12-24 hours
  • Delirium Tremens: 24-72 hours, up to 1 week

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of 12 beers per day for the past year comes into the emergency department complaining of headache, stomach upset and tremulousness after he abruptly quit drinking alcohol cold turkey earlier in the day. On examination, he is afebrile with normal vital signs. He is alert and oriented to person, place, time and situation. The man is diaphoretic and anxious. In this scenario, which one of the following characteristics best differentiates delirium from early dementia?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Both delirium and dementia can result in:
    • Behavioural disturbances
    • Cognitive deficits
    • Poor orientation
  • However, in all cases of delirium, there is an alteration (reduction) in the level of attention.
  • In early dementia, attention and concentration are typically maintained.

choices.text: Acamprosate is an FDA-approved anti-craving agent for the treatment of alcohol dependence.
Has a structure similar to amino acid taurine (derivative of homotaurine).
Safe in patients with renal impairment.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding Acamprosate:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Acamprosate is an FDA-approved anti-craving medication used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.
  • It is structurally similar to the amino acid taurine.
  • Action: Affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems.
  • Contraindicated in patients with Severe renal impairment and used with caution in those with moderate renal impairment.

Key Takeaways:

Acamprosate and Naltrexone are both FDA-approved medications for Alcohol dependence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old unresponsive woman is brought to the emergency department after an attempted suicide. Earlier that day, she refilled her monthly supply of a prescribed benzodiazepine for panic disorder. The pill bottle was empty when the paramedics found it on her nightstand. Ingestion of which of the following substances is most likely to exacerbate the outcome of her overdose?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Benzodiazepinesare rarely lethal in overdose by themselves.
  • However, when taken with other sedative-hypnotic drugs, especially alcohol, the effects of their potentiation can be lethal.
  • Cannabis (Option A), Cocaine (Option B), and Citalopram (Option C) are not known to potentiate the benzodiazepine overdose.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of daily IV heroin use for 18 years presents to a detoxification clinic in acute distress. She reports injecting "something different from her usual heroin" approximately 30 minutes before arrival, which was given to her by a peer. She complained of rhinorrhea, lacrimation, abdominal pain, myalgia, and irritability. Which of the following substances would be most likely to cause her current distress?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The patient's presentation is classic for precipitated opioid withdrawal, which occurs when a partial opioid agonist (like buprenorphine) or full antagonist (like naloxone) is administered to someone who is physically dependent on opioids.

Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist. When administered to someone dependent on full agonists (like heroin), it displaces the full agonist from receptors, resulting in acute withdrawal symptoms.

Opioid Withdrawal:

Withdrawal symptoms of opioids usually appear 6-8 hours* after the last dose, peak during 2-3rd day and subside during 7-10th.

Symptoms include:

  • Flu-like syndrome with symptoms like Rhinorrhea, Lacrimation, Sweating, diarrhoea
  • Yawning and piloerection (goose flesh or cold turkey).
  • Pupillary dilation (mydriasis)
  • Muscle cramps and generalised body aches
  • Insomnia, anxiety, HTN, tachycardia
  • Nausea, vomiting, and anorexia

Explanation of other options:

Alprazolam (Option A): Alprazolam, a benzodiazepine, causes drowsiness, ataxia.

Cocaine (Option C): Cocaine is a stimulant and intoxicant that causes mydriasis, agitation.

Methadone (Option D): Methadone and morphine are opioids that would cause further intoxication, not withdrawal.

Key takeaway:

An abstinence syndrome can be precipitated by the administration of an opioid antagonist (Naltrexone) or a partial agonist (Buprenorphine) in a patient actively using another opiate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a 14-year history of heavy tobacco use decides to abruptly stop smoking after being motivated by his wife's pregnancy. Despite multiple prior unsuccessful attempts to quit and initially declining pharmacotherapy, he relapses after three days due to withdrawal symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is characteristic of his present condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Nicotine Withdrawal:

  • Withdrawal from tobacco products (nicotine) can be severe, with a significant impediment to abstaining from use.
  • Withdrawal symptoms can develop within 2 hrs of smoking the last cigarette and can peak in the first 2 to 48 hrs.

Common withdrawal symptoms include:

  • Intense craving for tobacco
  • Psychological symptoms such as:
    • Anxiety
    • Anger
    • Depression
    • Irritability
  • Physical symptoms - increased appetite (Option B ruled out), insomnia (Option C ruled out), restlessness, difficulty concentrating, weight gain
  • Low heart rate and blood pressure.
  • Nausea and tremor are not commonly seen with tobacco withdrawal. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by friends after a night of partying. He is restless, agitated and sweating profusely. On examination, he has dilated pupils, elevated heart rate and high blood pressure. He also reports sensations of insects crawling on his skin. He is most likely intoxicated with which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The above-mentioned symptoms of agitation, diaphoresis, dilated pupils, hypertension, tachycardia, along with the sensation of insects crawling on the skin, are classic signs of cocaine intoxication.

Cocaine intoxication:

Cocaine (or other stimulants such as amphetamine) intoxication can present with:

  • Euphoria
  • Tachycardia, HTN
  • Pupillary dilation
    • Sweating
    • Moderate to high doses can cause paranoid ideations, auditory hallucinations, and visual illusions.
    • Tactile hallucination seen - Formication/Cocaine bugs/Magnan phenomenon
  • The most common mode of abuse is by snorting, which can result in naso-septal perforation.
  • Crack is a free base form of cocaine that is smoked. It's extremely potent, and a single dose can cause intense craving.
  • Speedball is a dangerous combination of cocaine and heroin, typically injected.
  • Cocaine bugs: A tactile hallucination where users feel like insects are crawling under or on their skin (also called formication).

Conversely, intoxication with alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines and opiates generally causes depression, somnolence and depressed vital signs (OPTIONS A, B, & C).

Key Takeaways:

Tactile hallucination seen in cocaine abuse - Formication/Cocaine bugs/Magnan phenomenon

questions.text: Gambling disorder comprises of all the following phases except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The isolation phase is not considered a phase in the progression of gambling disorder.

Four phases are seen in gambling disorder, namely:

  • Winning phase(Option A)
  • Progressive loss phase(Option B)
  • Desperate phase(Option C)
  • Hopeless phase

Gambling disorder is characterised by persistent and recurrent maladaptive gambling that causes economic problems and significant disturbances in personal, social or occupational functioning.

Aspects of the maladaptive behaviour include :

  • A preoccupation with gambling
  • The need to gamble with increasing amounts of money to achieve the desired excitement
  • Repeated unsuccessful efforts to control, cut back or stop gambling
  • Gambling as a way to escape from problems
  • Gambling to recoup losses
  • Lying to conceal the extent of the involvement with gambling
  • The commission of illegal acts to finance gambling
  • Jeopardising or losing personal and vocational relationships because of gambling
  • A reliance on others for money to pay off debts

choices.text: Gambling disorder is more common in women and older adults
Gambling is used as a way to escape problems
Withdrawal and tolerance are commonly seen

questions.text: All of the following receptors are involved in chocoholics except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Chocolate derived from the cacao bean is a substance of abuse.
  • Anandamide, an ingredient in chocolate, stimulates the same receptors as marijuana (Cannabinoid receptors) (Option A)
  • Other compounds in chocolate include tryptophan, the precursor of serotonin and phenylalanine, an amphetamine-like substance, both of which improve mood. (Option B, C)
  • So-called chocoholics may be self-medicating because of a depressive diathesis.

questions.text: A diagnosis of polysubstance addiction is appropriate for all of the following substances of abuse except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

In polysubstance dependence, an individual uses substances from at least three categories, but excluding nicotine and caffeine.

  • Substance users often abuse more than one substance.
  • A diagnosis of polysubstance dependence is appropriate if, for at least 12 months, a person has repeatedly used substances from at least three categories (not including nicotine and caffeine), even if the diagnostic criteria for a substance-related disorder are not met for any single substance, as long as, during this period, the criteria for substance dependence have been met for the substances considered as a group.
  • Two major treatment goals for the polysubstance abuse involve first abstinence from the substance, and the second is the physical, psychiatric, and psychosocial well-being of the patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old competitive bodybuilder reports a 6-year history of performance-enhancing regimens, beginning at age 19. His training protocols included 9-week cycles of injectable and oral compounds, resulting in rapid 9 kg muscle gains initially. He now describes uncontrollable mood swings, aggressive outbursts, and paranoid thoughts about competitors sabotaging him. Chronic use of such protocols most significantly increases the risk of which psychiatric condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The performance-enhancing regimens used here typically refer to the anabolic steroids.

Chronic use of androgenic-anabolic steroids is associated with a range of psychiatric conditions like psychotic episodes, manic symptoms and anti-social/aggressive behaviour.

  • Athletes and bodybuilders are common abusers of anabolic steroids since they help improve performance.
  • Androgenic anabolic steroids may initially induce euphoria and hyperactivity.
  • After relatively short periods, however, their use can become associated with increased anger, arousal, irritability, hostility, anxiety, somatisation and depression.
  • 2 to 15 per cent of anabolic steroid abusers experience hypomanic or manic episodes, and a smaller percentage may have psychotic symptoms.
  • Also disturbing is a correlation between steroid abuse and violence ("roid rage").
  • Steroid abusers with no record of antisocial behaviour or violence have committed murders and other violent crimes.
  • Testosterone cypionate, Nandrolone decanoate, Stanozolone, and Oxandrolone are examples of anabolic steroids.

choices.text: Alcohol has stronger effects when the blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is rising
Alcohol has stronger effects when the BAC is falling
Alcohol effects are unrelated to BAC
Alcohol has the same effect at any given BAC, regardless of direction

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Mellanby effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Mellanby's effect suggests that the intoxicating effects are greater when the blood alcohol concentration is rising than when it is falling.
  • For this reason, the rate of absorption bears directly on the intoxication response.

According to the Mellanby effect, subjects feel less drunk during the descending limb of the BAC-time curve than at the same concentration of alcohol on the ascending limb.

However, objective measures of impairment, especially those affecting motor coordination, reaction time, and driving skills, are generally worse during the descending limb for the same BAC.

All effects are dependent on a person's drinking history and the degree of intoxication.

Blood alcohol concentration is measured by breath analysers.

choices.text: Usual symptoms are personality change or psychomotor impairment

questions.text: True statements regarding Marchiafava-Bignami disease are all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Marchiafava-Bignami Disease is not caused by acute alcohol intoxication but is rather associated with chronic alcohol abuse, particularly in malnourished individuals.

Marchiafava-Bignami Disease:

  • A rare neurological complication of long-term alcohol use.
  • Pathophysiology is demyelination of the Corpus Callosum, optic tracts and cerebellar peduncles.
  • Predominantly seen in ill-fed patients with chronic alcohol abuse.
  • Patients often present with cognitive decline, personality changes, psychomotor slowing, and confusion.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Epilepsy
    • Ataxia
    • Dysarthria
    • Hallucinations
    • Intellectual disorientation
  • Management includes aggressive nutritional supplementation (Thiamine, folate, amantadine) along with alcohol withdrawal.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK526007/
